Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Severe Tropical Storm Kompasu, known in the Philippines as Severe Tropical Storm Maring[1] was a very large and deadly tropical cyclone that affected the Philippines, Taiwan, and southeast China.

Total_Death_Per_Country.Death_with_annotation: According to the National Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Council (NDRRMC), 43 people died from the storm in the Philippines, with 17 missing.
In Hong Kong, one person died and 21 people were injured.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: Of the dead, nine people died in landslides in Benguet.
Of the dead, ... five died in flash floods in Palawan.
In La Trinidad, Benguet, three children died after a mudslide buried their home.
Two people died after getting washed away by floodwaters.
One person died, and 21 people were injured.

Total_Summary_Insured_Damage.Total_Insured_Damage_Assessment_with_ann: According to Aon Benfield, economic losses outside the Philippines totaled US$118 million, with a grand total of US$245 million in economic losses.

Total_Insured_Damage_Per_Country.Total_Insured_Damage_Assessment_with_ann: According to the National Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Council (NDRRMC), 43 people died from the storm in the Philippines, with 17 missing. Damage is estimated at ₱6.4 billion (US$127 million).

The Hong Kong Observatory (HKO) issued the No. 8 Gale or Storm Signal during the approach of Kompasu, and kept it in force for over 23 hours. This was the longest No. 8 Signal ever recorded, beating the record of Tropical Storm Lionrock three days prior.

On 13 October 2021, heavy rains affected Zhejiang, Fujian, Guangdong, and Hainan provinces. In Guangdong, a total of 30 cities and counties suspended classes, the highest since Typhoon Mangkhut in 2018.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Insured_Da.Insured_Damage_Assessment_with_annotatio: According to the NDRRMC, damage is estimated at ₱3.85 billion (US$75.7 million).

The HKO recorded sustained winds of 75 mph (120 km/h) as the center of the storm passed by. There were 72 reports of fallen trees, and 10 reports of flooding. One person died, and 21 people were injured.
On 13 October 2021, heavy rains affected Zhejiang, Fujian, Guangdong, and Hainan provinces.

Total_Displacement_Per_Country.Displacement_with_annotation: The government opened 24 shelters, to which 255 people fled during the storm.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Displaceme.Displacement_with_annotation: Around 2,000 people were evacuated as a precaution.
In Cagayan, power outages were reported. Around 200 people were evacuated.
The government opened 24 shelters, to which 255 people fled during the storm.

Perils_Assessment_With_Annotation.Wind: Gale-force winds of over 70 km/h were generally recorded over the coastal areas, with gusts exceeding 62 mph (100 km/h) in some areas.
Perils_Assessment_With_Annotation.Rainfall: On 13 October 2021, heavy rains affected Zhejiang, Fujian, Guangdong, and Hainan provinces.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Building_D.Building_Damage_with_annotation: Of the dead, nine people died in landslides in Benguet and five died in flash floods in Palawan.
Of the dead, nine people died in landslides in Benguet and five died in flash floods in Palawan.
In La Trinidad, Benguet, three children died after a mudslide buried their home.
In Cagayan, power outages were reported. Around 200 people were evacuated.
On 13 October 2021, heavy rains affected Zhejiang, Fujian, Guangdong, and Hainan provinces.
Heavy rain lashed Shenzhen, where construction sites and tourist attractions were shut down.
The Yantian Port, one of the world's busiest ports, was closed, causing a maritime traffic jam.
There were 72 reports of fallen trees, and 10 reports of flooding.
Trees were brought down in Hainan, with firefighters clearing debris from roads.
Heavy rain was reported in numerous areas, including the Taipei–Keelung metropolitan area.

The government opened 24 shelters, to which 255 people fled during the storm.
